diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease commonly presents with symptoms such as fever, leukopenia, proteinuria (due to kidney involvement), pleural effusion, and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Although primarily known for joint involvement, it can cause systemic effects including pleural effusions, pericarditis, and can lead to leukopenia. Proteinuria could be a sign of secondary amyloidosis.

diagnoses.name: Viral Infections
diagnoses.rationale: Certain viral infections can cause a wide range of symptoms. For example, Parvovirus B19, HIV, and Hepatitis B and C can cause fever, leukopenia, proteinuria (through kidney involvement), and serositis leading to pleural effusion and acute pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This disease typically presents with signs and symptoms of several connective tissue diseases, including lupus, and can cause leukopenia, fever, pleural effusions, pericarditis, and proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma (Systemic Sclerosis)
diagnoses.rationale: Scleroderma can involve multiple organs including the skin, kidneys (leading to proteinuria), heart (pericarditis), and lungs (pleural effusion), and may also cause leukopenia and fever due to inflammation or secondary infections.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.rationale: This bacterial infection of the heart valves can cause fever, heart murmur (which could be confused with pericarditis if there is an accompanying pericardial effusion), leukopenia (less commonly), and renal complications leading to proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.rationale: TB can infect lungs causing pleural effusion, the pericardium leading to pericarditis, can indirectly cause proteinuria through kidney damage, fever due to infection, and leukopenia as a result of marrow involvement.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.rationale: Lymphomas can cause fever, leukopenia due to bone marrow infiltration or autoimmune phenomena, pleural effusion due to lymphatic obstruction or chest involvement, pericarditis, and proteinuria if there is kidney involvement.

diagnoses.name: Post-streptococcal Glomerulonephritis
diagnoses.rationale: Following a streptococcal infection, this condition can cause proteinuria due to kidney inflammation, and while less common, patients may exhibit symptoms like fever. Pleural effusion, leukopenia, and pericarditis are much rarer but feasible in a severe systemic response.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: A multisystem granulomatous disease, sarcoidosis can cause granulomas in the kidneys (proteinuria), lungs (pleural effusion), heart (pericarditis), and can lead to fever. Leukopenia is less common but can occur.

diagnoses: Uremia related to Chronic Kidney Disease
Hepatitis B or C with Cryoglobulinemia

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.reason: SLE can manifest with a wide range of symptoms including malar rash, autoimmune hemolysis, pleural effusion, pericardial effusion, and acute pericarditis, making it a primary consideration.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.reason: This disorder presents features of multiple autoimmune diseases including SLE, and can manifest with similar symptoms such as pleural and pericardial effusions.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.reason: Though primarily affecting joints, it can also have systemic manifestations like pericarditis and pleural effusions.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma (Systemic Sclerosis)
diagnoses.reason: Scleroderma can cause skin changes and internal organ involvement leading to symptoms like pleural and pericardial effusions.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.reason: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and skin rash, it can occasionally involve the heart and lungs, potentially leading to pleural and pericardial effusions.

diagnoses.name: Lupus-like syndrome
diagnoses.reason: Drug-induced lupus or other lupus-like syndromes can present with symptoms similar to SLE.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.reason: While not a classic presentation, infective endocarditis can result in autoimmune phenomena including hemolysis and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Evans Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: A rare autoimmune disorder characterized by autoimmune hemolysis and thrombocytopenia but can be associated with other symptoms like pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Viral Pericarditis
diagnoses.reason: Viral infections are a common cause of acute pericarditis and can sometimes cause pericardial and pleural effusions as part of a broader inflammatory response.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.reason: Certain types of lymphoma can present with autoimmune phenomena including hemolysis, as well as cause pericardial and pleural effusions.

diagnoses: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Shiga-toxin producing E. coli related Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome
Vasculitis (e.g., ANCA-associated, Behçet's Disease, Giant Cell Arteritis)
Infectious diseases (e.g., Viral or bacterial infections leading to secondary autoimmune responses)
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Immune Thrombocytopenia)
Viral hemorrhagic fevers (e.g., Ebola, Dengue Fever)
Rickettsial infections (e.g., Rocky Mountain spotted fever)

diagnoses.name: Asthma
diagnoses.description: Asthma is a condition in which your airways narrow and swell and may produce extra mucus. This can make breathing difficult and trigger coughing, wheezing, and shortness of breath.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
diagnoses.description: COPD is a chronic inflammatory lung disease that causes obstructed airflow from the lungs. Symptoms include breathing difficulty, cough, mucus (sputum) production, and wheezing.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: GERD occurs when stomach acid frequently flows back into the tube connecting your mouth and stomach (esophagus). This backwash (acid reflux) can irritate the lining of your esophagus, causing symptoms like dyspepsia.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.description: Leukemia is a cancer of the body's blood-forming tissues, including the bone marrow and the lymphatic system. It can cause basophilia, where there is an excess of basophil cells in the blood, and can also lead to symptoms like leukoplakia due to its impact on the immune system.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML)
diagnoses.description: CML is a type of cancer that starts in certain blood-forming cells of the bone marrow. It leads to an increased number of white cells, including basophils, in the blood.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: Vasculitis is an inflammation of the blood vessels. It happens when the body's immune system attacks the blood vessel by mistake. It can cause vascular anomalies and affect various organs.

diagnoses.name: Peptic Ulcer Disease
diagnoses.description: Peptic ulcer disease involves ulcers forming in the lining of your stomach, lower esophagus, or small intestine. It's typically the result of inflammation caused by the bacteria H. pylori, as well as from erosion from stomach acids. Dyspepsia is a common symptom.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: Iron deficiency anemia is a common type of anemia that occurs if you do not have enough iron in your body. People with the condition may experience dyspepsia. Basophilia can sometimes be associated as a reactive process.

diagnoses.name: Oral Candidiasis
diagnoses.description: Oral candidiasis, or thrush, is a fungal infection that occurs when there is overgrowth of a yeast called Candida in your mouth. It can lead to leukoplakia-like lesions on the mucous membranes.

diagnoses.name: Hypereosinophilic Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Hypereosinophilic syndrome is a blood disorder where there's an abnormally high number of eosinophils in the body, but basophilia can be present as an accompanying feature. It is marked by an intense inflammatory response affecting multiple organs, including the lungs, leading to symptoms like wheezing.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH)
diagnoses.reason: HLH can cause a wide range of symptoms, including fever, enlarged lymph nodes (lymphadenitis), and lung symptoms (dyspnea). Hyperferritinemia is a hallmark of the disease.

diagnoses.name: Behcet's disease
diagnoses.reason: Behcet's disease is a vasculitis that can cause oral ulcers (leading to oral pain), and may also affect the lungs and central nervous system, potentially explaining dyspnea and pseudoseizures.

diagnoses.name: Lupus erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.reason: Systemic lupus can cause a broad spectrum of symptoms including lymphadenitis and CNS involvement, which might manifest as pseudoseizures. Oral ulcers are common.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.reason: Sarcoidosis often presents with lymphadenopathy and can affect the nervous system and lungs, potentially explaining dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests. Hyperferritinemia may also be seen.

diagnoses.name: Adult Still's disease
diagnoses.reason: This inflammatory disorder is known for causing fever, sore throat (potentially perceived as oral pain), and hyperferritinemia. It may also lead to lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Sjogren's syndrome
diagnoses.reason: Sjogren's syndrome primarily affects the glands that produce tears and saliva, leading to dry mouth and potentially oral pain. It can also cause lymphadenopathy and lung involvement.

diagnoses.name: Mixed connective tissue disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.reason: MCTD can cause a wide range of symptoms, including lung involvement without direct pulmonary function impairment, oral ulcers, and hyperferritinemia.

diagnoses.name: Castleman's disease
diagnoses.reason: This rare condition is characterized by non-cancerous growths that can occur in the lymph node tissue, leading to lymphadenitis and can also cause systemic symptoms like fever and fatigue, potentially explaining some of the systemic symptoms seen.

diagnoses.name: NeuroBehçet's syndrome
diagnoses.reason: A subset of Behcet's disease that specifically affects the central nervous system, potentially explaining pseudoseizures. Oral ulcers are a common symptom of Behçet's disease.

diagnoses.name: Viral infections
diagnoses.reason: Certain viral infections can cause lymphadenitis, oral pain (e.g., herpangina), and neurologic symptoms (including pseudoseizures), along with transient hyperferritinemia and respiratory symptoms.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Acute Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A rapid progression disease that affects the blood and bone marrow, characterized by an excess of white blood cells.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that originates in the lymphatic system, often causing lymphadenopathy and affecting white blood cell count.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can affect multiple organs, commonly the lungs and lymph glands, causing dyspnea and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Often known as 'mono' or the 'kissing disease', this is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) and can cause leukocytosis, lymphadenopathy, and dysphagia.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of lymphoma that can affect the lymphatic system, leading to symptoms such as lymphadenopathy and dyspnea.

diagnoses.name: Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A diverse group of blood cancers that include any kind of lymphoma except Hodgkin's lymphomas, symptoms can include leukocytosis and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV)
diagnoses.description: A virus that attacks the immune system, can cause a wide range of symptoms including lymphadenopathy and leukocytosis in its initial stages.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of the body, commonly causes leukocytosis and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, can cause lymphadenopathy and dyspnea.

diagnoses.name: Thyroiditis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the thyroid, which can cause dysphagia due to anatomical proximity and might indirectly relate to other symptoms through systemic effects.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that affects the blood and bone marrow. It can explain symptoms like hyperthermia, easy bleeding, and lymphadenitis due to the effects on blood cells and the immune system.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: Cancer that begins in infection-fighting cells of the immune system, called lymphocytes. These cells are in the lymph nodes, spleen, thymus, bone marrow, and other parts of the body. Can cause lymphadenitis, hyperthermia, and easy bleeding.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Often called mono or 'the kissing disease,' this infection is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) and can lead to fever (hyperthermia), swollen lymph nodes (lymphadenitis), and potential spleen enlargement that might cause easy bleeding.

diagnoses.name: Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) Associated Lymphoproliferative Disorders
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, which can lead to fever, swollen lymph nodes, and in severe cases, can affect the central nervous system, potentially leading to seizures.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human immunodeficiency virus progressively fails the immune system, leading to severe infections and diseases such as lymphadenitis. It can also cause symptoms like fever (hyperthermia) and, in advanced stages, make the body prone to bleeding and seizures.

diagnoses.name: Aplastic Anemia
diagnoses.description: A rare condition in which the body stops producing enough new blood cells, leading to fatigue, hyperthermia, and easy bleeding.

diagnoses.name: Primary Immunodeficiency Disorders
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders in which part of the body's immune system is missing or does not function properly, potentially leading to lymphadenitis, easy bleeding, and complications that could provoke seizures.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels, which can cause easy bleeding under the skin and other symptoms depending on the organs affected. Severe cases might impact the nervous system, causing seizures.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that causes the immune system to attack its tissues, causing widespread inflammation and damage to the affected organs, including potential lymphadenitis, fever, and, in severe cases, seizure disorders due to neurological involvement.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout your body, leading to symptoms including fever, sores in the mouth (which might appear similar to leukoplakia), and various systemic symptoms, potentially including those related to the central nervous system.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that affects the white blood cells and tends to progress slowly. It can lead to monocytosis and increased immunoglobulins.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body, including the joints, skin, kidneys, heart, lungs, blood vessels, and brain. It can lead to miscarriages and dyspnea.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints but can also have systemic effects, including monocytosis and increased immunoglobulins. It has been associated with miscarriages.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that increases the risk of blood clots. It is known for causing recurrent miscarriages and can lead to dyspnea if pulmonary embolism happens.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Myeloma
diagnoses.description: A cancer of plasma cells that can cause increased immunoglobulins and may lead to symptoms such as dyspnea due to anemia or kidney problems.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition where the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormone. It can lead to miscarriages and dyspnea alongside other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can affect multiple organs in the body, primarily the lungs. Patients may experience dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests.

diagnoses.name: Polyarteritis Nodosa
diagnoses.description: A serious blood vessel disease that can cause high blood pressure, miscarriages, and various systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Churg-Strauss Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A disorder marked by blood vessel inflammation that can cause asthma, sinus problems, and a rise in eosinophils, which may coincide with monocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Primary Immunodeficiency Disorders
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders where part of the body's immune system is missing or does not function properly, leading to increased levels of immunoglobulins and vulnerability to infections, which can indirectly lead to some of the symptoms listed.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue, non-restorative sleep, and potentially pain, among other symptoms. The fatigue significantly interferes with daily activities and work.

diagnoses.name: Mastocytosis
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by the accumulation of mast cells in the skin and other parts of the body. It can cause skin lesions ('tags'), bone pain, and can contribute to blood pressure lability due to the release of histamine.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic condition causing episodic attacks of angioedema (swelling) due to deficiency or dysfunction of the C1 inhibitor protein. It does not usually cause itching or hives like allergic angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory and mood issues. Patients may experience non-restorative sleep and various somatic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones. Symptoms can include fatigue, increased sensitivity to cold, constipation, dry skin, weight gain, and muscle weakness.

diagnoses.name: Secondary Hypertension
diagnoses.description: High blood pressure that's caused by another medical condition. It can be due to various conditions that affect your kidneys, arteries, heart, or endocrine system and lead to blood pressure lability.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Myeloma
diagnoses.description: A cancer of plasma cells, immune system cells in bone marrow that produce antibodies. Symptoms may include bone pain, fatigue due to anemia, and infections.

diagnoses.name: Primary Sleep Disorders
diagnoses.description: Disorders such as insomnia or sleep apnea that directly affect sleep, potentially leading to non-restorative sleep and daytime fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Pheochromocytoma
diagnoses.description: A rare tumor of adrenal gland tissue. It may cause high blood pressure spikes, headaches, episodes of sweating, and rapid heartbeats.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease in which the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue. It can affect the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs, and may cause a wide range of symptoms, including fatigue, joint pain, and skin lesions.

diagnoses: Adjustment disorder with mixed anxiety and depressed mood

diagnoses.name: Acute Otitis Media
diagnoses.description: An infection of the middle ear, typically associated with fluid accumulation and inflammation, potentially leading to symptoms like ear pain, fever, and in some cases leukocytosis as the body responds to the infection.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Otitis Media
diagnoses.description: A persistent infection or inflammation of the middle ear, which could contribute to weight gain through decreased activity due to illness or medication side effects.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, presenting with symptoms such as fever, sore throat, swollen lymph nodes (lymphadenitis), and leukocytosis. It may sometimes present with angiomata.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer of the lymphatic system. It can cause symptoms such as lymphadenitis, weight gain (possibly due to decreased metabolism or as a side effect of treatment), leukocytosis, and in some cases, rare types of vascular growths.

diagnoses.name: Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: Another type of lymphoma affecting the lymphatic system, causing enlarged lymph nodes, weight gain, and leukocytosis. It may present with skin lesions that could resemble angiomata.

diagnoses.name: Cytomegalovirus Infection
diagnoses.description: A common virus infection that can cause symptoms such as fever, sore throat, swollen glands, and leukocytosis. It is also known to cause more severe complications in immunocompromised patients, possibly including angiomata.

diagnoses.name: Bacterial Sepsis
diagnoses.description: A severe infection entering the bloodstream can lead to systemic inflammation, leukocytosis, and organ dysfunction. Patients might experience rapid weight gain due to fluid retention.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection that primarily affects the lungs but can also impact other parts of the body, leading to lymphadenitis, weight gain (especially in the recovery phase), and leukocytosis during active infection.

diagnoses.name: Staphylococcal or Streptococcal Skin Infections
diagnoses.description: These bacterial infections can cause lymphadenitis and leukocytosis. In severe cases, such infections may lead to systemic symptoms like fever and weight gain (due to inflammation and fluid retention). Certain types may also be associated with skin angiomata.

diagnoses.name: Kaposi's Sarcoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that forms in the lining of blood and lymph vessels. While angiomata are more directly related to Kaposi's sarcoma, it can also cause lymphadenopathy and, in advanced stages, systemic symptoms that could indirectly influence weight.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: An allergy-related condition that causes inflammation of the nasal passages, often accompanied by symptoms like runny nose (coryza), irritated eyes, and sometimes ear issues.

diagnoses.name: Atopic Dermatitis (Eczema)
diagnoses.description: A condition that can cause inflammation of the skin, leading to itchy and irritated skin, which may relate to hyperactivity due to discomfort.

diagnoses.name: Conjunctivitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation or infection of the outer membrane of the eyeball and the inner eyelid, causing redness and irritation of the eyes.

diagnoses.name: Contact Dermatitis
diagnoses.description: A skin reaction resulting from exposure to allergens or irritants, potentially causing ear irritation similar to otitis externa symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Hyperlipidemia
diagnoses.description: A condition of elevated lipid levels in the blood, which can contribute to atherosclerosis.

diagnoses.name: Hypertension
diagnoses.description: High blood pressure, often related to or a contributor to atherosclerosis.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A metabolic disorder that can lead to various complications, including atherosclerosis.

diagnoses.name: ADHD (Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder)
diagnoses.description: A brain disorder marked by ongoing patterns of inattention and/or hyperactivity that interferes with functioning or development.

diagnoses.name: Environmental Allergies
diagnoses.description: Reactions to environmental triggers, such as pollen, dust, or pet dander, can cause symptoms like coryza and irritated eyes.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Otitis Externa
diagnoses.description: Ongoing inflammation of the outer ear and ear canal, which can present similar symptoms to acute otitis externa but lasts longer.

diagnoses: Hepatitis (various forms, including A, B, C)

diagnoses.description: Endometriosis
diagnoses.comments: Direct correlation with the primary symptom.

diagnoses.description: Anxiety disorders
diagnoses.comments: Obsessive-compulsive behavior can be a sign.

diagnoses.description: Sjögren's syndrome
diagnoses.comments: Connects to irritated eyes, poor healing, and potentially dysgeusia due to dry mouth.

diagnoses.description: Vitamin deficiencies
diagnoses.comments: May explain poor healing and dysgeusia. Vitamin B12 or zinc deficiencies are common culprits.

diagnoses.description: Autoimmune diseases
diagnoses.comments: Endometriosis can have autoimmune aspects; combined symptoms could suggest broader autoimmune dysfunction.

diagnoses.description: Ocular surface disease
Diabetes
diagnoses.comments: Poor healing can be a symptom; dysgeusia might also be related.

diagnoses.description: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD)
diagnoses.comments: Directly related to obsessive-compulsive behavior symptoms.

diagnoses.description: Chronic Dry Eye Syndrome
diagnoses.comments: Explains the symptom of irritated eyes.

diagnoses.description: Thyroid disorders
diagnoses.comments: Can potentially explain a range of symptoms including poor healing and dysgeusia.

diagnoses.name: Common Variable Immune Deficiency (CVID)
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by low levels of serum immunoglobulins and increased susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL)
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that affects the blood and bone marrow, often leading to decreased immunoglobulin production and increased risk of infection.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: A viral infection that progressively compromises the immune system, leading to increased susceptibility to other infections and certain types of cancer.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can affect multiple organs, causing granulomas and potentially leading to decreased immunoglobulins and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Lymphoproliferative Syndrome (ALPS)
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the immune system leading to an increase in lymphocytes and increased risk of lymphadenopathy and autoimmune manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, inherited immune deficiency characterized by eczema, thrombocytopenia, recurrent infections, and an increased risk of autoimmune diseases and malignancies.

diagnoses.name: Selective Immunoglobulin A (IgA) Deficiency
diagnoses.description: An immunodeficiency disorder characterized by an absence or severely reduced levels of immunoglobulin A, leading to increased susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: Hyper IgM Syndromes
diagnoses.description: A group of rare genetic disorders resulting in a failure to produce immunoglobulins G, A, and E, leading to increased risk of infections and potentially lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Castleman Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder characterized by non-cancerous growths that may develop in the lymph node tissue throughout the body, potentially leading to symptoms like decreased immunoglobulins and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Idiopathic CD4+ Lymphocytopenia
diagnoses.description: A rare condition with unexplained decrease of CD4+ T lymphocytes, leading to increased susceptibility to infections, lymphadenopathy, and potentially hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes
diagnoses.rationale: Known for hypermobility; associated conditions can lead to autonomic dysfunction, manifesting as blood pressure lability.

diagnoses.name: Marfan Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Connective tissue disorder that may present with hypermobility; cardiovascular manifestations might explain blood pressure lability.

diagnoses.name: Loeys-Dietz Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: A connective tissue disorder characterized by hypermobility and vascular manifestations, which might relate to blood pressure lability.

diagnoses.name: Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (POTS)
diagnoses.rationale: Commonly associated with hypermobility syndromes; can cause blood pressure lability and may be linked with autonomic dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: May present with joint hypermobility and autonomic dysfunction, including blood pressure lability.

diagnoses.name: Mast Cell Activation Syndrome (MCAS)
diagnoses.rationale: Can be associated with hypermobility and may cause a wide range of symptoms including tinnitus and blood pressure changes.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.rationale: Autoimmune disease that could explain tinnitus and autonomic symptoms such as blood pressure lability, though less commonly associated with hypermobility.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.rationale: Autoimmune disease that can cause a wide range of symptoms; might include monocytosis and could possibly relate to hypermobility.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily affecting the joints, could potentially be linked with hypermobility at early stages and may cause systemic symptoms like those described.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: An autoimmune condition that could explain sinutitis and potentially blood pressure lability through autonomic involvement.

diagnoses: Diabetes Mellitus – related complications might include glycemic lability and, in severe cases, could affect hearing.
Chronic Infection – long-standing infections might lead to leukocytosis and dysgeusia.
Autoimmune Diseases (e.g., lupus, Sjögren's syndrome) – these can cause a wide variety of symptoms including dysgeusia and hearing loss.
Sleep Apnea – mainly associated with non-restorative sleep but can also affect glycemic control due to stress and hormone dysregulation.
Acute Otitis Media or other Ear Infections – could explain hearing loss and leukocytosis.
Zinc Deficiency – can lead to dysgeusia and has been associated with hearing loss.
Drug Adverse Effects – certain medications could cause leukocytosis, dysgeusia, and hearing loss.
Meniere's Disease – primarily affects hearing but may also influence sleep due to discomfort or vertigo.
Head and Neck Cancers – depending on location and nerves affected, can lead to dysgeusia and hearing loss.
Hypertension/Cardiovascular Disorders – can lead to non-restorative sleep and, in complex cases, affect hearing through blood circulation.
Mucous Cyst of the Oral Mucosa

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myeloid Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that starts in certain blood-forming cells of the bone marrow. It can lead to increased levels of various types of white blood cells and affects other blood cells, causing symptoms like fatigue, weight loss, and enlarged spleen.

diagnoses.name: Graves' Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that leads to overactivity of the thyroid gland (hyperthyroidism). Symptoms may include anxiety, hand tremor, heat sensitivity, weight loss, puffy eyes, and enlarged thyroid.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that causes the bone marrow to make too many red blood cells. These excess cells thicken the blood, slowing its flow, and can cause complications like blood clots.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body, including skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs. Symptoms can be mild or life-threatening.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that can lead to widespread inflammation. While it primarily affects joints, it can also cause systemic symptoms, including low white blood cell count.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: An infection typically caused by the Epstein-Barr virus. It's characterized by swollen lymph nodes, fever, sore throat, and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Hypersplenism
diagnoses.description: Condition in which the spleen is overactive, leading to the premature destruction of blood cells. This can result in leukopenia, anemia, and thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer of the lymphatic system. It can cause lymphadenitis, an enlargement of the lymph nodes, and affect the body's ability to fight infection.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It primarily affects the lungs but can also affect lymph nodes, leading to lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: Although not directly related to hyperthyroidism or polycythemia, it can be associated with systemic conditions or nutritional deficiencies that might indirectly affect overall health, including immune response and oxygen transportation.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's disease and Ulcerative Colitis)
Secondary Angioedema due to ACE Inhibitors
Irritable bowel syndrome with associated respiratory symptoms

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache that is often accompanied by visual disturbances (scintillation) and other sensory symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death, causing symptoms such as aphasia and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, it presents similar to a stroke but with temporary symptoms, including weakness and aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the membranes surrounding the brain and spinal cord, symptoms can include headache, vertigo, and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain, which can cause headaches, weakness, and aphasia among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves, leading to symptoms including vertigo and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance, sometimes including loss of consciousness or aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition resulting from restricted blood flow to the back of the brain, causing symptoms like vertigo, headache, and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A focal collection within the brain parenchyma, which can present with headache, weakness, aphasia, and sometimes altered consciousness.

diagnoses.name: Hemorrhagic Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when a weakened blood vessel ruptures and bleeds into the surrounding brain, with symptoms including headache, weakness, and possibly aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition characterized by intense headaches often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Vestibular Neuronitis
diagnoses.description: An inner ear condition that causes inflammation of the vestibular nerve, leading to vertigo.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear that can lead to dizzy spells (vertigo) and hearing loss.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death, causing symptoms such as weakness, vertigo, and impaired speech.

diagnoses.name: Dehydration
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs when you use or lose more fluid than you take in, leading to symptoms like weakness, headache, and nausea.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain, which can cause headaches, nausea, vomiting, and other neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system) that can cause weakness, vertigo, and other neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Gastroenteritis
diagnoses.description: An intestinal infection marked by watery diarrhea, abdominal cramps, nausea or vomiting, and sometimes fever.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by reduced blood flow to the back part of the brain, resulting in symptoms like vertigo, weakness, and dizziness.

diagnoses.name: Hypoglycemia
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by a very low level of blood sugar (glucose), leading to symptoms such as weakness, nausea, and headache.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms. It's frequently characterized by intense, debilitating headaches. Symptoms may include nausea, vomiting, difficulty speaking, numbness or tingling, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear that leads to episodes of feeling like spinning (vertigo), ringing in the ears (tinnitus), hearing loss, and a fullness in the ear. It typically affects only one ear.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain. Symptoms can vary greatly depending on the brain tumor's size, location, and rate of growth.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. Symptoms include weakness, tingling, numbness, and blurred vision. Other signs are muscle stiffness, thinking problems, and urinary problems.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma
diagnoses.description: A benign tumor that develops on the cranial nerve that runs from the brain to the inner ear and controls balance and hearing. Symptoms may include hearing loss on one side, ringing in the ear, and balance problems.

diagnoses.name: Temporal Arteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disorder that affects the large blood vessels of the scalp, neck, and arms. Symptoms include severe headaches, jaw pain, vision problems, and scalp tenderness.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. Symptoms may include trouble speaking and understanding what others are saying, paralysis or numbness of the face, arm, or leg.

diagnoses.name: Migrainous Infarction
diagnoses.description: A rare type of ischemic stroke occurring during a migraine attack. It involves a migraine with aura symptoms accompanied by prolonged neurological symptoms that are proven to correspond to an area of brain ischemia.

diagnoses.name: Otosclerosis
diagnoses.description: An abnormal bone growth in the middle ear that causes hearing loss. Symptoms include hearing loss that starts in one ear and may move to the other, ringing in the ears, and dizziness.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition in which you lack enough healthy red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to your body's tissues. Symptoms include fatigue and weakness.

diagnoses: Rheumatoid Arthritis with Secondary Sjögren's Syndrome
Chronic cutaneous lupus erythematosus (Discoid lupus erythematosus)
Vasculitis (e.g., Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis, Microscopic Polyangiitis)
Rheumatoid Arthritis with secondary Sjögren's syndrome
Chronic cutaneous lupus erythematosus (Discoid lupus erythematosus)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE is a chronic autoimmune disease that can affect various organs and tissues of the body causing symptoms like pleural effusion, oral ulcers, and in some cases, may lead to postinflammatory dyspigmentation and synovitis.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Rheumatoid arthritis can cause synovitis and, in more severe cases, lead to pleural effusion. It's also associated with skin manifestations, which could explain postinflammatory dyspigmentation and occasional oral ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Behcet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Behcet's disease is a rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body. It is well known for causing oral ulcers and can also lead to pleural effusion and postinflammatory dyspigmentation. Joint inflammation or synovitis is also a symptom.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: MCTD is an autoimmune disorder that shares characteristics of three other conditions: systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma, and polymyositis. This can manifest as synovitis, oral ulcers, pleural effusion, and sometimes postinflammatory skin changes.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: Sarcoidosis involves the growth of tiny collections of inflammatory cells in different parts of the body, including the skin, causing postinflammatory dyspigmentation, lungs (leading to pleural effusion), and possibly affecting the joints (synovitis). Oral ulcers are less commonly reported but can occur.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.rationale: Tuberculosis, particularly extrapulmonary tuberculosis, can present with pleural effusion, and oral ulcers. While less common, it can also affect the skin and joints causing postinflammatory dyspigmentation and synovitis.

diagnoses.name: Sjogren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Sjogren's syndrome primarily affects the body's moisture-producing glands, leading to symptoms like oral ulcers. It can also cause joint inflammation (synovitis) and has been associated with lung involvement, potentially leading to pleural effusion.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: Vasculitis refers to conditions that involve inflammation in the blood vessels, which can lead to symptoms scattered throughout the body, including oral ulcers, skin changes like postinflammatory dyspigmentation, joint pain or synovitis, and in certain types, pleural effusion.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.rationale: Drug-induced lupus is a lupus-like syndrome that occurs due to long-term use of certain drugs. Symptoms can mirror those of SLE, including pleural effusion, oral ulcers, and potentially joint and skin involvements.

diagnoses.name: Stevens-Johnson Syndrome/Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily known for causing severe skin reactions, Stevens-Johnson Syndrome/Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis can lead to oral ulcers and may have complications affecting the lungs (like pleural effusion) and potentially joints.

diagnoses: Chemical Exposure (e.g., to cytostatics or other immunosuppressants)
Infectious diseases (secondary causes of the above syndromes, such as Hepatitis B or C associated vasculitis)
